body.p:
Frankfort Mar 15/64
To His Excellency
Governor Bramlette

The undersigned states that in the year 1857, by the Owsley Circuit Court, one Jos Redwine was fined ten dollars for an offense not now remembered, for the payment of which I became security. Said fine has never been paid, and since the rebellion broke out, said Redwine has been in the Southern Confederacy giving aid to the enemy, and unless remitted the whole burden will fall upon me. John Dishman is was the prosecuting Attorney and he also is in the rebel army on service. This application is respectfully made for a remission of so much as is within the power of your excellency. I am and have been loyal to the government and state. I served eighteen months in the 8th Ky Infantry and the execution has been issued since my return from the army.

We the undersigned citizens of Owsley, in Frankfort on business, are well
acquainted with Abraham Gum_ Know him to be a good citizen, that he has faithfully served as a solider, and join in his petition, which we know to be true.

Witness
James Harlan for the three names
David Price
Asa Smith
Thomas Rock
G. M. Calmes
Wm B Gum
John T Gum Capt
John B. Phillips
John Congleton
G. W. Hieronymous
A E Howerton
W. C. Howerton

Owsley County
Abram Gum's petition
Refused
Tho E Bramlette
64
